div.head: TO DAVID GARDINER, ESQ Cornet in Sir John Cope's Regiment of Dragoons.
div.p: WHILE my heart is following you with a truly paternal Å¿olicitude, through all the dangers of military life, in which you are thus early engaged, anxious for your Å¿afety amidÅ¿t the inÅ¿truments of death, and the far more dangerous allurements of vice; I feel a peculiar pleaÅ¿ure in being able at length, though after Å¿uch long delays, to put into your hands the MEMOIRS with which I now preÅ¿ent you. They contain many particulars, which would have been worthy of your attentive notice, had they related to a perÅ¿on of the moÅ¿t diÅ¿tant nation or age: But they will, I doubt not, command your peculiar regard, as they are Å¿acred to the memory of that excellent man, from whom you had the honour to derive your birth, and by whoÅ¿e generous and affectionate care, you have been laid under all the obligations, which the beÅ¿t of fathers could confer on a moÅ¿t beloved Å¿on.

Here, Sir, you Å¿ee a gentleman, who with all the advantages of a liberal and religious education, added to every natural accompliÅ¿hment that could render him moÅ¿t agreeable, entered, before he had attained the Å¿tature of a man, on thoÅ¿e arduous and generous Å¿ervices to which you are devoted, and behaved in them with a gallantry and courage, which will always give a Å¿plendor to his name among the BritiÅ¿h Å¿oldiery, and render him an example to all officers of his rank. But alas! amidÅ¿t all the intrepidity of the Martial Hero, you Å¿ee him vanquiÅ¿hed by the blandiÅ¿hments of pleaÅ¿ure,
and in chace of it plunging himÅ¿elf into follies and vices, for which no want of education or genius could have been a Å¿ufficient excuÅ¿e. You behold him urging the ignoble and fatal purÅ¿uit, unmoved by the terrors which death was continually darting around him, and the moÅ¿t Å¿ignal deliverances by which Providence again and again reÅ¿cued him from thoÅ¿e terrors; till at length he was reclaimed by an evermemorable interpoÅ¿ition of divine grace. Then you have the pleaÅ¿ure of Å¿eeing him become in good earneÅ¿t a convert to ChriÅ¿tianity, and by Å¿peedy advances growing up into one of its brighteÅ¿t ornaments; his mind continually filled with the great ideas which the goÅ¿pel of our Redeemer Å¿uggeÅ¿ts, and bringing the bleÅ¿Å¿ed influence of its Å¿ublime principles into every relation of military and civil, of public and domeÅ¿tic life. You trace him perÅ¿evering in a Å¿teady and uniform courÅ¿e of goodneÅ¿s, through a long Å¿eries of honourable and proÅ¿perous years, the delight of all that were Å¿o happy as to know him, and, in his Å¿phere, the moÅ¿t faithful guardian of his country; till at laÅ¿t, worn out with honourable labours, and broken with infirmities which they had haÅ¿tened upon him before the time, you Å¿ee him forgetting them at once at the call of duty and Providence; with all the generous ardour of his moÅ¿t vigorous days ruÅ¿hing on the enemies of religion and liberty, Å¿uÅ¿taining their Å¿hock with the moÅ¿t deliberate fortitude, when deÅ¿erted by thoÅ¿e that Å¿hould have Å¿upported him, and chearfully Å¿acrificing the little remains of a mortal life, in the triumphant views of a glorious immortality.

This, Sir, is the noble object I preÅ¿ent to your view; and you will, I hope, fix your eye continually upon it, and will never allow yourÅ¿elf for one day to forget, that this illuÅ¿trious man is COLONEL GARDINER, your ever honoured father; who having approved his fidelity to the death and received a crown of life, Å¿eems as it were, by what you here read, to be calling out to you from amidÅ¿t the cloud of witneÅ¿Å¿es with which you are Å¿urrounded, and urging you by every generous, tender, filial Å¿entiment, to mark the footÅ¿teps of his ChriÅ¿tian race, and Å¿trenuouÅ¿ly to maintain that combat, where the victory is through divine grace certain, and the prize an eternal kingdom in the heavens.

My hopes, Sir, that all theÅ¿e powerful motives will eÅ¿pecially have their full efficacy on you, are greatly encouraged by the certainty which I have of your being well acquainted with the evidence of ChriÅ¿tianity in its full extent; a criminal ignorance of which, in the midÅ¿t of great advantages for learning them, leaves Å¿o many of our young people a prey to DeiÅ¿m, and Å¿o to vice and ruin, which generally bring up its rear. My life would be a continual burthen to me, if I had not a conÅ¿ciouÅ¿neÅ¿s in the Å¿ight of God, that during the years in which the important truÅ¿t of your education was committed to my care, I had laid before you the proofs both of natural and revealed religion, in what I aÅ¿Å¿uredly eÅ¿teem to be, with regard to the judgment, if they are carefully examined, an irreÅ¿iÅ¿table light; and that I had endeavoured to attend them with thoÅ¿e addreÅ¿Å¿es, which might be moÅ¿t likely to impreÅ¿s your heart. You have not, dear Sir, forgotten, and I am confident you can never entirely forget, the aÅ¿Å¿iduity with which I have laboured to form your mind, not only to what might be ornamental to you in human life, but above all to a true taÅ¿te of what is really excellent, and an early contempt of thoÅ¿e vanities by which the generality of our youth, eÅ¿pecially in your Å¿tation, are debaÅ¿ed, enerva â¢ ed, and undone. My private as well as public addreÅ¿Å¿es for this purpoÅ¿e will, I know, be remembered by you, and the tears of tenderneÅ¿s with which they have Å¿o often been accompanied: And may they be Å¿o remembered, that they who are moÅ¿t tenderly concerned, may be comforted under the loÅ¿s of Å¿uch an ineÅ¿timable friend as Colonel Gardiner, by Å¿eeing that his character, in all its moÅ¿t amiable and reÅ¿plendent parts, lives in you; and that how difficult Å¿oever it may be to act up to that height of expectation, with which the eyes of the world will be fixed on the Å¿on of Å¿uch a father, you are, in the Å¿trength of divine grace attempting it; at leaÅ¿t are following him with generous emulation, and with daily Å¿olicitude, that the Å¿teps may be leÅ¿s unequal!

May the Lord God of your father, and I will add, of both your pious and honourable parents, animate your heart more and more with Å¿uch views and Å¿entiments as theÅ¿e! May he guard your life amidÅ¿t every Å¿cene of danger, to be
a protection and bleÅ¿Å¿ing to thoÅ¿e that are yet unborn; and may He give you, in Å¿ome far diÅ¿tant period of time, to reÅ¿ign it by a gentler diÅ¿Å¿olution than the hero from whom you Å¿prung; or if unerring wiÅ¿dom appoint otherwiÅ¿e, to end it with equal glory.

closer.signed: I am, Dear Sir, Your ever faithful, Affectionate Friend, and Obliged humble Å¿ervant, P. DODDRIDGE.
